summary: This document is a series of email exchanges between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel regarding preparations for an upcoming suppression hearing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The emails discuss legal briefs, exhibits, and procedural questions, including the identity of Stan Pottinger and Maxwell's filing strategy.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the suppression hearing and related legal motions. Her defense attorneys filed multiple memoranda of law.

persons.name: Stan Pottinger
persons.context: Identified as a lawyer who represented the plaintiff in a civil action related to the case. His identity was queried in the emails.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Mentioned as the judge who will resolve the suppression motions ahead of trial.

persons.name: Judge Sweet
persons.context: Referenced in a query about an original application submitted to him.

persons.name: Judge S
persons.context: Mentioned in a query about whether there was a transcript before this judge.

persons.name: Judge McMahon
persons.context: Referenced in relation to proceedings and an opinion (Ex D, E, G) that were attached for review.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's case and will resolve her suppression motions.
Pottinger represented the plaintiff in a civil action related to the Maxwell/Epstein case, placing him in an adversarial legal relationship.

events.title: Email exchange re: Maxwell suppression hearing
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discuss and share documents related to Ghislaine Maxwell's upcoming suppression hearing, including her briefs and prior court transcripts.

events.title: Follow-up on exhibits and identities
events.description: Further emails are exchanged to share Exhibit H and clarify the identity of Stan Pottinger.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense filed 12 separate Memoranda of Law (MOLs) as a strategy to evade the court's page limits.
Judge Nathan indicated she would resolve the suppression motions 'at a later time' ahead of trial.
Stan Pottinger was a lawyer at Boies Schiller who represented the plaintiff in a related civil action.
The emails reference attached exhibits including prior court transcripts (McMahon proceedings) and legal briefs.
The correspondence shows internal prosecution preparation for a significant suppression hearing in Maxwell's criminal case.
